content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is interesting, and well thought out. The Coder has presented the challenge in a clear manner, while making it fun. I like gamified challenges, and this one is cool (like ice).

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a fun little problem like many others that I've seen on here that takes the form of fighting a simple RPG fight

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun RPG clash of code ^^ It could even be a reverse mode, as the variables are almost self-explanatory.

Why in your solution you have:
    while (monsterHealth >= 0) or (aiHealth >= 0) do
    begin
        if monsterHealth <= 0 then break;
        if aiHealth <= 0 then break;
Isn't it easier to write simply
    while (monsterHealth > 0) or (aiHealth > 0) do
    begin
?

- Input/Line 6 is the same as line 3 "monster's element"
- Output/Line 2: you speak about the "amount of damage [...] remaining": maybe it is better to speak about remaining health points?
- Maybe specify what you mean by "fainting" (that health points are less than or equal 0)
Then I will approve it, it is sufficiently easy for a CoC, an fun to solve.

I think you can split it in 2 clashes of code, 
It is a great idea anyway.

Binary output issue
* Based on the contribution guidelines, binary output should be avoided for clashes. That is to say, there should be more than 2 possible answers in total for all cases. Please revise the output requirement to fix the issue.

Goal
* Please elaborate "double damage". Is input damage "base damage" that should be doubled if the element types match those stated in the rules? If yes, please mention that, and also specify in Input section that the damage given is "base" damage.

Input
* Please rewrite all descriptions in the following format:
<<Line _:>> [variable type] [[variable_name]] [description]

For example, line 1 becomes:
<<Line 1:>> An integer [[monsterHealth]] for the monster's starting health.

* Please remove the extra space before ":" for Line 3 and Line 6.

* Line 6: "aiELement" should be changed to "aiElement".

Constraints
* You've mixed up > with <. For example, "0 > monsterHealth" means "0 is greater than monsterHealth" (or monsterHealth is less than zero). Please fix the signs.

* Please format all [[variables]].

Thanks.
Thank you for your thoughtful and considerate feedback. I believe all the issues you have raised have now been addressed.
Thanks for commenting, I think you may well be right! I am happy to simplify the task if enough people think that would be best.

This is fantastic feedback, I think all your points are spot on, and I've edited the contribution to reflect your advice. I do believe the statement is easier to understand because of it, thank you for your thoughtful contribution.

While that is technically better code, it seems to change the logic of when the loop ends and fails all the tests when I tried it in the IDE. 

If I remember right, I originally wrote it the way you suggested, and had the task so that the AI attacked first. But thought it might be better both the AI and the monster attacked  at the same time and I used breaks to solve it.
In fact It should better work with  while (monsterHealth > 0) AND (aiHealth > 0) do (emphasis added ^^)
Nice one! I've changed the solution code, thanks for the feedback.

Thank you for making the changes. The matters below need to be followed up based on the revised version:

Goal
* Please format "Fight" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

* Please change "flight" to "Flight", format the word as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

* Please mention that element may be {{fire}}, {{ice}} or {{water}} (remember to format the three words as constants).

Output
* Please format "Fight" and "Flight" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Constraints
* >= is wrong too (similar to the logic mentioned last time). Please change them all to â‰¤.

Cases
* "A clear victory" Test violates the last constraint. Please fix the constraint and/or the case.

* "Validator 3" violates the second constraint. Please fix the constraint and/or the case.

Thanks again.

Nice one, really helpful advice! Thanks for the general tips and pointers regarding the style required, I apologize for the sloppy errors that slipped through. I would hope it's ok now, but I'm sure you'll be able to find more mistakes!
You're welcome! And don't worry, I can't find more issuesâ€¦ for now ðŸ˜› (and hopefully later too!)
Sorry to bother you, but I was wondering whether you think it would be better to remove the element types in order to simplify the task for clash of codes?
Well, in my opinion having the element types makes the clash more interesting while just slightly more complex. It's fine in the current state. But you may also want to wait to see others' opinions.
